unnormalised: **Energy & Utilities News Snippet: Load Shedding in Kerala Intensifies**
normalised: **Energy and Utilities News Snippet: Load Shedding in Kerala Intensifies**

unnormalised: Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala – Ongoing load shedding across Kerala has intensified, impacting both residential and commercial consumers. Kerala State Electricity Board (KSEB) officials cited a dip in hydroelectric power generation due to lower than expected monsoon rainfall in the catchment areas of the Idukki and Sabarigiri reservoirs as the primary cause.
normalised: Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala – Ongoing load shedding across Kerala has intensified, impacting both residential and commercial consumers. Kerala State Electricity Board (K S E B) officials cited a dip in hydroelectric power generation due to lower than expected monsoon rainfall in the catchment areas of the Idukki and Sabarigiri reservoirs as the primary cause.

unnormalised: The unscheduled power cuts, lasting up to 2 hours in some areas, are disrupting daily life and affecting businesses. Many small-scale industries, particularly in the food processing sector that rely heavily on electricity, are facing production losses. This is particularly concerning ahead of Onam celebrations, when demand for electricity peaks due to increased cooking (including the preparation of elaborate Onam Sadhya feasts) and festive lighting.
normalised: The unscheduled power cuts, lasting up to two hours in some areas, are disrupting daily life and affecting businesses. Many small-scale industries, particularly in the food processing sector that rely heavily on electricity, are facing production losses. This is particularly concerning ahead of Onam celebrations, when demand for electricity peaks due to increased cooking (including the preparation of elaborate Onam Sadhya feasts) and festive lighting.

unnormalised: KSEB Chairman, Mr. Ravi Menon, stated that efforts are underway to procure additional power from the national grid, but transmission bottlenecks and high costs (Rs. 8 per unit) pose significant challenges. He urged consumers to conserve electricity during peak hours (6 PM to 10 PM) and assured that KSEB is working diligently to minimize the inconvenience. A review meeting is scheduled for August 29th to assess the situation and explore alternative solutions.
